title: Strategic diversity? Counterplay? LC$ players want a tiny pool of terribly designed champions.
body:
LCS level players want the tournament scene to be a small pool of balanced champions with high reliability. Anytime a low counterplay high power champion like {{champion:39}}  becomes viable they become insanely popular in the LCS.

LCS pro’s don’t want extra decision making, counterplay, strategic diversity or team reliance; they want powerful and obvious optimal strategies. I would say they are the worst group of players in the world to talk to about DESIGN. (Not balance.)

In their heart of hearts LCS players do not want to learn how to play against the full champion roster in a tournament setting, they don’t want abilities that have serious attached counterplay, they don’t want to have to co-ordinate perfectly to set up a play, they don't want to play champions with any real "risk".

The backlash from high level players at the removal of ward hopping on {{champion:64}}  is typical of that mentality. Ward hopping with safeguard removes a massive amount of decision making and team reliance. Remove ward hopping, extend safeguard’s range, slightly extend sonic wave’s range, suddenly Lee Sin has to make decisions instead of having an optimal skill path available 90% of the time.

Why the hell would someone who's career is based around winning games want to risk missing a Sonic Wave? If ward hopping was removed Lee would have to co-ordinate with initiators and safeguard to them have reliable initiation and make the LC$ big plays... blasphemy to someone who wants to make 100% reliable plays anytime, anywhere with any team composition.

Lee is a terrible design and it is time to stop making DESIGN decisions to cater to a tiny portion of the player base that only wants to win as safely and reliably as possible; fun and good design be damned.

replies.body:
It is absolutely true that competitive players have little interest in good design values.  They will vastly prefer highly general champions with low counterplay.  You know, things like Irelia and Lucian.

The task of the designer is to force them, so much as is possible, to play a wide variety of champions situationally.

This is not really a different task than the task of a card game or board game designer -- the player wants to find an optimal strategy that works against everything, while the designer wants to provide a variety of strategies that are all good or bad situationally..

I will mention that the backlash against removing Lee's ability to ward hop was not an exclusively high level thing.  Players of all skill levels came out of the woodwork to protest.

Its true that the backlash was hardly limited to the pro scene, but the pro scene definitely has the most to lose when the always good, zero counterplay champions get nerfed.

I don't know if removing ward hopping is the "best" decision or not, but it is a really good example of where the pro scene's interests lie.

You're absolutely correct.  Further, it doesn't follow that the best thing for the game is what pro players want.  Sometimes, Riot will need to make a decision that makes the game better for the fans, rather than better for the pros.

But when you take a look at the statistics on that, it shows how much Riot favors the pros.  Over season 4, literally all of the champions that were nerfed were played by the pros, with the exception of 1 ({{champion:24}}) who was only nerfed because he was cheesing normals so hard he had a ban rate equal to Season 3 Kassadin's.

Hang on, I think you misunderstand the situation.  If we are seeing Riot nerf legitimately OP champs, that's good for everyday players and it's good for fans.

Pros play OP champion X.  Riot nerfs X.  This is generally bad for the pros playing X (which is approximately all of them in that role); they need to figure out some new way of winning games.

You are completely correct. I may have come off a little more {{champion:64}} hostile than strictly necessary, but he is the hot issue at all elo's right now. In the pro scene he is useful in any team comp on the planet even if he is 0-5-1.

Why bother to master situational champions like {{champion:111}}  {{champion:48}} {{champion:31}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:131}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:120}}  {{champion:11}} {{champion:72}} {{champion:106}} when you can just use the hell out of {{champion:64}} and {{champion:59}} ? There are barely any teams that they don't work with and they aren't truly ban-worthy.

This is pretty much as accurate as it gets, and why balancing around what the pros do is a train wreck waiting to happen.

This is what happens with games where content is constantly being added. The cream rises to the top. No matter how hard Riot tries they'll never able to balance this many champions against each other to a degree most people would find satisfying. The champions that can do more with less will always have the competitive edge. If you want an analogue, look at Magic: the Gathering. In the entire 15,000ish collection of unique printed cards, only a few hundred actually see competitive play in the formats in which the entire pool is available, and even fewer than that see widespread play. The strongest ones always push out every thing else.

If Riot really wants to take a whack at shaking up the competitive scene without this ridiculous cycle of buffs and nerfs where nobody is happy, try segmenting the available champion pool at any given tournament, similar to the different formats in M:tG like Standard/Modern/Legacy. For a given tournament or match, force teams to chose from a semi-randomly selected champion pool of X champions. It will force pros to move outside their comfort zone and use a wider array of champions instead of the same top 20 or so that usually get played.

They have a pool of like 20 at best that see competitive play in one strategy and that's how they like it, despite it being dreadfully boring to watch and more so to play. Also your MTG analogy doesn't work because on top of the whole common/uncommon/rare/mythic thing that sets card power, they also flat out just make bad cards because that's their business model. Unless you're willing to say Riot intentionally makes bad champions (which frankly, they do, or rather they obliterate the champions they don't want played), it's not a valid comparison.

I always felt the entire issue with Lee is that he's RIGHT on that precipice of being blatantly OP. Its not so much that "Hey, this champ is better than Lee, so we clearly must nerf them." but more like "Woah, thats pretty damn super strong, lets tone is back a bit." Lee is basically the pinnacle, the last line. If you've passed him, then chances are, that champion is way too strong.

Granted, that being said, I think theres plenty of options to tune Lee while still keeping his core. Remove his spell vamp, make his Q1 cost more energy but have his Q2 refund some, and reduce the base damage of his ult considerably but have it increase damage for each unit the kicked target hits.

I totally agree.  It's so dumb that so many of the "decisions" they make in their games are so obvious that it feels like there are barely any decisions they actually have to make in the games.  It almost feels like just watching 10 AIs play or something.  Since they can do so many reliable, low counterplay things, then IMO the LCS has become dreadfully boring to watch because almost exclusively only the highly predictable happens.  Their so-called "big plays" are only big plays to those that don't have that great of an understanding of the game.  Lee can make what others call a "big play" very easily and reliably with little that can be done to stop in a lot of cases.
It is a huge advantage to be able to know exactly what the optimal play for you current champion is.

Remember, when Riot wanted to nerf Lee Sin, but Lee Sin players convinced them not to? One of their main arguments for Lee Sin being balanced, was the Diamond from Gambit said so. If someone who knows Lee Sin as well as Diamond, says that Lee Sin is balanced - then he must be balanced, right?

Well nope. Why would Diamond want his best pick to get nerfed? Of course he would defend it.

Another example that I can think of: When is it a bad time for {{champion:412}} to throw out his lantern? 

What if Thresh could not collect souls while the ability is on cooldown? Maybe not the best solution but it is a start.
That's actually a ridiculously bad idea.
I never said it was a good idea, only an idea. Why is it bad though?

Because Thresh's only way of gaining armor is through souls. So, lets say you're constantly put in positions that require to use your lantern. You enter late game with 16 base armor compared to others 100.

He does have scaling armor and mres like any champ does. This is a bad idea more so that, his souls is his income on any kind early game tankiness. Removing the ability to gather souls while his lantern toss is on cd completely negates his lane presence/engage early as the longer he stays in lane, the stronger he gets. Like any champ, of course. But, say there's a Leona on the opposite team, right? The only way for Thresh to outscale Leona who can buff her current armor and mres by quite a bit is through the usage of the souls mechanic.

So, it's not that it's his only way of gaining armor. It's his only way of gaining any early game potency aside from his lock down ability, and can gap close through his lantern usage.

Edit: through* not throw
Actually Thresh does NOT have scaling armor and MR. His base armor is always 16 and base MR is 30

The same thing happens with fighting games there the top 4 or 5 safest characters are tournament mainstays and everyone else is picked maybe once by a rogue player. I simply used MtG because it's the one I'm more familiar with. It happens with literally every game where players are allowed to select from a large pool at will. 

Also; rarity doesn't actually follow power level, although it is a decent baseline indicator if you're new. However, a common from the newest set was just banned/restricted in every format, so there's that.

It's also not entirely fair to say Riot is intentionally making bad champions -- with the exception of the Eve tier where they clearly would rather just disable the champion until they're ready to rework them but don't so do the next best thing so nobody plays them -- but again, the cream rises. Olaf is not an objectively bad champion. He used to see good play up top with his true damage. The problem is he's terrible *in relation to* other champions that are commonly picked now. He has no mobility and can't really lane or jungle as well as others now, so he gets left in the dust. Or Shyvanna? She actually has a very quick jungle clear and pretty great AoE-DPS in a teamfight, but she still doesn't see play in a world where everyone and their mother has an escape ability tacked on. If the champion pool were segmented, it's very possible that an environment would happen in which champions like this suddenly because viable. That's something I'd rather see.
